content.question: In each of two separate experimental trials, two blocks are free to move along a straight, horizontal track, as shown in the figure. In each trial, one block is initially moving to the right on a section of track with negligible friction. A second block is initially at rest at the edge of a rough track section, where the coefficient of kinetic friction between the rough section and each block is <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>. The two blocks collide and stick together. After colliding, the blocks move some distance – the “travel distance” − along the rough section before coming to a stop. The travel distance is long compared to the sizes of the blocks. In Trial <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the initially-moving block has mass <math alttext="M sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> and an initial velocity <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and the other block has mass <math alttext="M sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math>. In Trial <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the initially-moving block has mass <math alttext="2 M sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> and initial velocity <math alttext="one half v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and the other block is the same block of mass <math alttext="M sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math> that was used in Trial <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. (a) The travel distances are <math alttext="D sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="D sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in trials <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, respectively. Indicate how <math alttext="D sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="D sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> compare to each other._____<math alttext="D sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="D sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. _____<math alttext="D sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="D sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. _____<math alttext="D sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="D sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> are equal.Without citing or manipulating equations, justify the claim you selected.
